intro: Brassica bracteata, commonly known as the narrow-leafed mustard, is a flowering plant in the mustard family, Brassicaceae. It is native to regions of Asia, including China, India, and the Himalayas, and thrives in temperate climates. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–100 cm, featuring alternate, lance-shaped leaves and small, yellow flowers arranged in racemes. Its fruit is a slender, elongated silique that contains several seeds. Brassica bracteata is often found in disturbed soils and can be an invasive species in some areas.
